text:
Economic gap between North East and London will widen by £57bn, report warns 13:00, 5 Oct 2016 14:43, 5 Oct 2016 By Graeme Whitfield Study says North East economy will grow in the next 10 years but won't keep pace with cities in the South East Share Get business news by email Niall Baker, Irwin Mitchell 
The economic gap between the North East and London will widen by £57.2bn in the next 10 years, despite the region’s largest cities experiencing significant growth during the second quarter of 2016, a new report says. 
Law firm Irwin Mitchell’s latest UK Powerhouse report, which has been produced with the Centre for Economic and Business Research (Cebr), says Newcastle’s economy grew by 2.2% in the second quarter of the year and Sunderland’s by 2.3%, but both cities were significantly outpaced by others in the South East. 
The study authors predict that by 2026, London’s economy will expand by 16.3%, higher than the levels expected for Newcastle, Sunderland and Middlesbrough, which will see growth by the same period of 12.9%, 11.9% and 8.2% respectively. 
The study predicts that the gap between London and the North East region will grow by £57.2bn between now and the second quarter of 2026. 
If correct, the study would pose questions for the Government after two years of the Northern Powerhouse strategy aimed at re-balancing the economy away from London and towards the North. 
Prime Minister Theresa May has widely been seen as being less keen on the strategy than former Chancellor George Osborne, but she has re-affirmed her commitment to the project and today said that she wants a “revival of our great cities”. 
Niall Baker, CEO at Irwin Mitchell’s business legal services division, said: “There has been a significant amount of political uncertainty over the last couple of months so it is pleasing to see that there has been a recovery of growth rates in the North East region. 
“What is perhaps more significant however is the lack of progress is tackling the divide between London and the North. The Northern Powerhouse initiative has now had the backing of Theresa May and other senior MPs and it’s vital the Government refocuses its efforts in this area and ensures economic prosperity is shared fairly.” Read More Tackling gender pay gap could boost economy by billions of pounds, report says 
Irwin Mitchell produced its first UK Powerhouse report last year, which report predicted a growing economic gap between the South East and the North of England. 
The report made nine policy recommendations in a call for the Government to radically rethink how it looks to rebalance the UK’s economy. Among the recommendations was the establishment of more industry clusters around UK universities, the introduction of a regional living wage and the devolution of air passenger duty to English regions. 
Output in Britain’s manufacturing sector reached its highest level for more than two years as the industry continued to bounce back from a post-Brexit vote slump. Figures for the services sector also showed a recovery after a shock contraction after the Brexit vote.
